subject: RE: [junit] The "final" keyword
msgSnippet: ... Same here.  Immutable objects are nice.  Once they re created you don t have to worry about them. ... I read, I think it was in Effective Java that one
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetevha@...]
> Sent: Thursday, September 18, 2003 3:56 PM
> To: JUnit
> Subject: [junit] The "final" keyword
>
> I particularly like final on member variables. I am a BIG
> fan of creating immutable objects -- I like for my objects to
> be in a sane state when they are created.

Same here. Immutable objects are nice. Once they're created you don't
have to worry about them.


> I tend to like final on classes.

I read, I think it was in "Effective Java" that one should either design
their classes to be extendable or prevent the class from being
extendable. So if you don't intend for your class to be extended then
it should be declared to be final, have all the constructors private, or
public constructors with final methods.

Kris
